advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE FLYER - VERSO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET - INSIDE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>1983 Hannover show advert. <br><br> Advert said that 30,000 Kaypro II systems were already sold in the U.S.A.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The high performance Computer System for practice-oriented applications." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Students have a heap particularity which we cared about"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEMOTECH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Each day, go on the computing road''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">No one knows better than Microsoft how to increase your TRS-80 BASIC's power. Microsoft created the TRS-80 Level ll and Disk BASIC plus the industry standard Microsoft BASIC...<br><br> ...Microsoft Level lll BASIC is an enhancement to the Level ll. It contains all Disk BASIC features not already in Level ll and it adds six new Level lll exclusives...<br> ...Advanced graphics is Level lll's most exciting addition to the TRS-80 - and it's exclusive. Draw a line, outline or solid box by specifying just two points, then save it and put it back with BASIC statement. You'll find yourself writing more programs with charts, graphs and even animation...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LUCAS LOGIC BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT MARCH 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, March 1982 issue.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INTERACTION NEWSLETTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Three issues of this 'Newsletter Detroit Interact Group' were published during the first semester of 1980</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> IIE VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>Promotional picture. Notice the dual floppy drive module on top of the case, inspired by the Franklin <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/museum/computer.asp?st=1&c=646" target="_blank">ACE 1200</a><p class="petitgris">Roberto Isiri</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH (STUPID) PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Family life scene in front of a complete Atmos system carefully lined up on the coffee table in the living room, with a minimum of visible cables. <br><br> The flaw?... No, it is not that it is rather difficult to use such a serious configuration for hours sitting on the floor. The flaw comes rather from the photographer who forgot to do the housework before taking the picture and left to posterity his accessories cartons right behind the low dresser.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french brochure presented games from #1 to #43</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The sound, the color, the intelligence''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Japanese selling price was of 58.000 yen.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (MAR. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said<br><br><font color="#666666"> The electric typewriter's days are numbered. Because now there's a machine that put real wordprocessing power within everyone's reach.<br> The Amstrad PCW 8256 is a complete word-processor and a powerful computer in one unit.<br> And it's unbelievably low price includes a screen with built-in disc drive, keyboard, printer and word processing software...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Why paying more ?"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
The Nec APC III appears to be the U.S. version of the NEC PC-9801, which was made in a variety of configurations.
This machine was partially IBM PC compatible, but neither the PC bus or BIOS were cloned. It had an NEC 7220 graphics chip which was not directly CGA compatible, but was much higher resolution, and quite fast for its day.
The CPU is an 8086 running at 8 MHz with 128K of memory. The system used an OEM version of MS-DOS 2.11, modified to work with its non-standard BIOS and hardware. Simple DOS applications that did not make use of IBM BIOS calls or of lower-level hardware would work.
Optionally there was an expansion board called SLE (for Software Library Expander) which some nicknamed the SLEeze board. This board included a second 8086 processor, Phoenix BIOS and memory. In conjunction with its accompanying software this board allowed for "more PC compatibility" by emulating a true PC clone with CGA graphics. Accounts of how well this actually worked vary.
NEC also ported a version of System III UNIX and released it as PC-UX available as an optional OS. NEC also provided a hardware-based virtual memory paging board for PC-UX which helped performance.
Other options included a 10MB hard drive. Memory was expandable to 640K.
Thanks to Richard Bramante for information and pictures.
computer.keyboard: 101-key with 12 function keys, cursor and numeric keypads
computer.media: 2 internal TEAC FD-55B-01-U 5.25'' floppy drives - 720 KB in native mode, 360 KB with the SLE board
computer.name: APC III
computer.ports: Floppy Disk Drive, RS-232C, Printer, C-bus slot x 6
computer.price: About $3,000 with internal 10 MB hard drive 1984

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Keyboard connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Monochrome monitor plug<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> External HDD controller card housing<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Colour RGB monitor DB9 plug<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Configuration switches<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Serial RS-232 interface connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> Two additional serial ports <br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> Parallel printer connector </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> EXPANSION CARD SLOTS</strong></font><br><blockquote>An extra memory card is inserted in one of the four expansion slots.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Chevy</b></p></blockquote>
